getExpectedThreshold

public java.lang.Double getExpectedThreshold()
Gets the expectedThreshold value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Returns:
expectedThreshold The expected threshold establishes a statistical significance threshold for reporting database sequence matches. The default value is 10, meaning that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance. Lower expected thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Increasing the expected threshold shows less stringent matches and is recommended when one is performing searches with short sequences as a short query is more likely to occur by chance in the database than a longer one, so even a perfect match (no gaps) can have low statistical significance and may not be reported. Increasing the expected threshold allows you to look further down in the hit list and see matches that would normally be discarded because of low statistical significance. Generally a value of up to 1000 is enough to see results.

setExpectedThreshold

public void setExpectedThreshold(java.lang.Double expectedThreshold)
Sets the expectedThreshold value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Parameters:
expectedThreshold - The expected threshold establishes a statistical significance threshold for reporting database sequence matches. The default value is 10, meaning that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance. Lower expected thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Increasing the expected threshold shows less stringent matches and is recommended when one is performing searches with short sequences as a short query is more likely to occur by chance in the database than a longer one, so even a perfect match (no gaps) can have low statistical significance and may not be reported. Increasing the expected threshold allows you to look further down in the hit list and see matches that would normally be discarded because of low statistical significance. Generally a value of up to 1000 is enough to see results.

getExtendGap

public java.math.BigInteger getExtendGap()
Gets the extendGap value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Returns:
extendGap Gap extension penalty that is added to the standard gap open penalty for each base or residue in the gap. This is how long gaps are penalised - if you don't want long gaps, increase the extension gap penalty. Usually one can expect a few long gaps rather than many short gaps, so the gap extension penalty should be lower than the gap penalty. An exception is where one or both sequences are single reads with possible sequencing errors in which case one would expect many single base gaps. One can get this result by setting the gap open penalty to zero (or very low) and using the gap extension penalty to control gap scoring.

setExtendGap

public void setExtendGap(java.math.BigInteger extendGap)
Sets the extendGap value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Parameters:
extendGap - Gap extension penalty that is added to the standard gap open penalty for each base or residue in the gap. This is how long gaps are penalised - if you don't want long gaps, increase the extension gap penalty. Usually one can expect a few long gaps rather than many short gaps, so the gap extension penalty should be lower than the gap penalty. An exception is where one or both sequences are single reads with possible sequencing errors in which case one would expect many single base gaps. One can get this result by setting the gap open penalty to zero (or very low) and using the gap extension penalty to control gap scoring.

getFilter

public java.lang.Boolean getFilter()
Gets the filter value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Returns:
filter The filter allows one to mask out various segments of the query sequence for regions which are non-specific for sequence similarity searches. Filtering can eliminate statistically significant but biologically uninteresting reports from the output, for example hits against common acidic-, basic- or proline-rich regions, leaving the more biologically interesting regions of the query sequence available for specific matching against database sequences. Filtering is only applied to the query sequence, not to database sequences. The program used for this, with nucleotide query sequences is known as DUST. The SEG program is used for filtering low complexity regions in amino acid sequences from one's protein query sequence. The default is false for protein searches and true for nucleotide searches.

setFilter

public void setFilter(java.lang.Boolean filter)
Sets the filter value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Parameters:
filter - The filter allows one to mask out various segments of the query sequence for regions which are non-specific for sequence similarity searches. Filtering can eliminate statistically significant but biologically uninteresting reports from the output, for example hits against common acidic-, basic- or proline-rich regions, leaving the more biologically interesting regions of the query sequence available for specific matching against database sequences. Filtering is only applied to the query sequence, not to database sequences. The program used for this, with nucleotide query sequences is known as DUST. The SEG program is used for filtering low complexity regions in amino acid sequences from one's protein query sequence. The default is false for protein searches and true for nucleotide searches.

getGapAlignment

public java.lang.Boolean getGapAlignment()
Gets the gapAlignment value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Returns:
gapAlignment Whether to perform optimised alignments within regions involving gaps. If set to true, the program will perform an alignment using gaps. Otherwise, it will report only individual HSP (High-Scoring Segment Pair) where two sequence match each other, and thus will not produce alignments with gaps.

setGapAlignment

public void setGapAlignment(java.lang.Boolean gapAlignment)
Sets the gapAlignment value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Parameters:
gapAlignment - Whether to perform optimised alignments within regions involving gaps. If set to true, the program will perform an alignment using gaps. Otherwise, it will report only individual HSP (High-Scoring Segment Pair) where two sequence match each other, and thus will not produce alignments with gaps.

matrix Scoring (comparison) matrix to use when searching the database. Supported matrices inludes: BLOSUM45, BLOSUM50, BLOSUM62, BLOSUM80, BLOSUM90, PAM30, PAM70, PAM250.

getOpenGap

public java.math.BigInteger getOpenGap()
Gets the openGap value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Returns:
openGap Penalty for the first residue in a gap, i.e. score taken away for the initiation of the gap in sequence or in structure. To make the match more significant one can try to make the gap penalty larger. It will decrease the number of gaps and if one has good alignment without many gaps, its Z-score will be higher.

setOpenGap

public void setOpenGap(java.math.BigInteger openGap)
Sets the openGap value for this NCBIBlastInputParameters.

Parameters:
openGap - Penalty for the first residue in a gap, i.e. score taken away for the initiation of the gap in sequence or in structure. To make the match more significant one can try to make the gap penalty larger. It will decrease the number of gaps and if one has good alignment without many gaps, its Z-score will be higher.
